Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Development of 40Ar/39Ar Intercalibration Pipettes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Potassium (K), one of the more abundant elements in the Earth?s crust is found in many rock forming minerals. One of the isotopes of K, 40K is radioactive and decays to 40Ar. This scheme forms the physical basis for one of the most common geochronologic techniques applied to rocks and minerals. In recent years, a special technique requiring neutron bombardment of samples to produce 39Ar from 39K has become more favored than the traditional ?K-Ar? method, referred to as the 40Ar/39Ar method. In fact, the 40Ar/39Ar method of radioisotopic dating has the broadest range of applicability of any geochronometer, being useful from early solar system formation (~4.56 billion years ago) to volcanic materials as young as 2,000 years old. These studies cover topics such as volcanic and seismic hazards, timing and extent of mineralization events, global climate change and variability, paleomagnetic reversal timescale, and dating the fossil record, including human evolution. Thus any improvement in the accuracy and precision 40Ar/39Ar method will improve our understanding of the timing and rates of geologic processes.

Despite exemplary precision, recent experiments conducted via the EARTHTIME initiative have revealed significant interlaboratory inconsistencies such that ages determined by different labs may vary by us much as 4 %, approximately an order of magnitude larger than typical reported measurement precision. Four possible causes for these discrepancies have been identified; 1) differences in the data reduction protocols employed by the participating laboratories; 2) unaccounted nonlinearity of the mass spectrometer source/detector systems used to collect the data; 3) unrecognized heterogeneity in the mineral standards or an experimental artifact arising from variations in neutron irradiation dosage in some of the sample packages; and 4) incomplete degassing or isotopic fractionation of Ar from the analyzed sanidines in various laboratories. This research project addresses the issue of interlaboratory consistency by developing an argon pipette system that will travel between the participating 40Ar/39Ar labs within the United States. The pipette system will deliver gas samples with exactly the same isotopic composition(s) and similar gas volume(s), thus controlling the variables and issues associated with heterogeneity of natural samples. In addition, variable gas sample volumes from the pipette system will also be measured to assess the response linearity of noble gas mass spectrometers. The ultimate goal of this study is to intercalibrate the various NSF supported 40Ar/39Ar laboratories and allow for the direct comparison of the ages produced from the participating labs, at the level of 0.1% or better. The long-term use of the pipette system will maintain the calibration between the 40Ar/39Ar laboratories. Undergraduate and graduate students will be traveling with the intercalibration pipette assisting with the measurements. This will provide the students the opportunity to see, work, and interact with personnel from the different 40Ar/39Ar laboratories and serve as a unique training opportunity for the next generation of geochronologist/isotope geochemists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
STATEMENT OF THE PROBLEM:  Improvements in the accuracy and precision of ages determinations advance our understanding rates of natural processes.

40Ar/39Ar age measurements, conducted as part of the U.S. National Science Foundation sponsored EARTHTIME initiative, (http://www.earth-time.org), using two of the most commonly used 40Ar/39Ar mineral standards, Fish Canyon (FC) and Alder Creek (AC) sanidines, revealed significant inconsistencies among the inter-laboratory results.  The dispersions between the reported ages range from 1173 to 1200 ka (~2%), approximately an order of magnitude larger than the typical reported analytical errors.

Five likely causes for these discrepancies that were identified at the EARTHTIME 4 meeting in Denver in 2009;

  1. Differences in the data reduction protocols employed by the participating laboratories- this was a significant topic of the conversation at the meeting.
  2. Unaccounted nonlinearity of the mass spectrometer source/detector systems used to collect the data.
  3. Unrecognized heterogeneity in the mineral standards.
  4. Experimental artifact arising from variations in neutron irradiation dosage in some of the sample packages.

In an effort to discover the actual cause(s) of these inconsistencies within the inter-laboratory data set, two Argon Inter-calibration pipettes (APIS-1 and -2) have been constructed. The calibrated APIS were shipped to five the participating EARTHTIME 40Ar/39Ar labs (Rutgers University, Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, Columbia University, Berkeley Geochronology Center, Arizona State University, and New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology) and to the U.S. Geological Survey 40Ar/39Ar labs, Menlo Park, CA and Denver CO

RESULTS:  The APIS experiment has allowed us to make major progress towards documenting the sources of the dispersion in the original EARTHTIME intercalibration experiment. In addition to the traveling APIS, many labs have been developing and testing "best practice" procedures and making improvements as a result of the initial experiment. Therefore, the community is working seriously toward the common goal of 0.1% comparability. As you may imagine we are not of one mind, and there is still more to be done. However, I would argue that at this point we have isolated the three potential causes of the observed dispersion:

  1. Isotopic fractionation, we discovered that the reference gas (usually atmospheric Ar) during the pipette loading process was fractionated (This definitely happened in the LDEO lab during the spin up to the APIS test- Hemming made follow-up experiments to test the amount of time needed to insure equilibration and was able to fix the problem. It highlights, however the possibility that it could also happen in other labs and it would have an effect on age calculations of standards with large differences in composition). We reported these findings at the William Smith meeting in Londo.
  2. Pressure dependent instrumental mass fraction. This is a well-known phenomena that occurs within the ion-source. Isotopic fraction can also occur in a secondary electron multiplier (SEM) detector. Both the LDEO and Rutgers labs have run experiments that demonstrate a pressure effect on the measured ratio. Neither lab had this problem during the measurement of the APIS gas (over the factor of 7 range of gases measured)
  3. What we refer to as the “Time Zero” (TZ) factor.  This may have the largest effect on the FC/AC experiment because the great difference in age requires that the isotopes not all evolve on the same trends. If the isotopes are all on the same trends, TZ does not matter. The TZ factor has the greatest impact on the results when one isotope (i.e. 39Ar) increases during the course of a measurement of one gas (FC) and decreases during the course of a measurement of the other gas (AC). Our gasses in the APIS have by design the same 40Ar signal for air, FC and AC. This means the 39Ar of the FC is ~25X lower than that of the AC. So where TZ estimate of the pairs of 40Ar and 39Ar for these two samples can have a significant effect on the R value (ratio of the ratio of 40Ar*/39Ar).

The APIS experiment has allowed us to make major progress towards documenting the sources of the dispersion in the original EARTHTIME intercalibration experiment. In addition to the traveling APIS, many labs have been testing best procedures and making improvements as a result of the initial experiment. The results from the APIS study indicate that the between-lab comparability of isotopic measurements may be controlled to better than the  ± 2-3‰ level.

These Improvements in the accuracy and precision of ages determinations will advance our understanding rates of natural processes particularly changes in seismic and volcanic activity, resulting in our ability of asses geologic hazards such as earthquakes and volcanic eruptions.
